WRITING.TEXT: The DNA proform of the HIV virus was eliminated from the mice, as stated in the first sentence of the discussion. It would be next to impossible to have viral replication without the proper coding sequence of the virus.
the only way this is misleading is when the data is misinterpreted. I even provided a summary which explained the data as well.
This is not true...your interpretation of the data is inaccurate.
nowhere does it say it is a cure

"To our knowledge, this study is the first to demonstrate the effective excision of HIV-1 proviral DNA from the host genome in pre-clinical animal models using saCas9 and multiplex sgRNAs delivered by an all-in-one AAV-DJ/8 vector."
It's kind of difficult to have HIV infection if there is no viral DNA to replicate and make more virus

as shown in Figures 4 and 5. So, saying that it "eliminated HIV-1 infection" is way overstated.
Actually, the title says eliminates..which it does, it does not say completely eliminates. You pulled it over semantics.

It is definitely as awesome as it sounds, from a technology standpoint. it will be some time before we will see it in practical use curing disease..but most scientists believe it's only a matter of time
Theoretically yes. But there still remain a lot of practical obstacles.
As a former malaria researcher, I can tell you it is VERY hard ;)
It's going to take a number of years..but its getting there. CRISPR clinical trials for other diseases like cancer are set to begin this summer.
If anything, they would try to use CRISPR to make more deadly biological weapons..but it's certainly not easy. Saying its a massive threat to humanity is a bit if an overreach ;)

It's not a cure yet....but it's certainly a step in the right direction. The work was done in mice..but what are called humanized mice..in which their immune systems are reconstituted with human immune cells...making it a much more biologically relevant model. That being said, it still needs to be tested on humans.

Well, as of yet there haven't been any reports of CRISPR mutations and/or resistance. It's probably due to the fact that those pieces of DNA don't last very long..they do their job and then the cell will usually degrade the excess DNA

It certainly not out of the realm of possibility....however, researchers are jus beginning to understand the molecular mechanisms surrounding CRISPR technology...so I think that level of understanding is still a ways off.
The researchers used transgenic mice that allow them to be infected by the HIV virus...a well-established animal model for HIV research.

WRITING.TEXT: Well, the pH portion is only within the realm of fiction as the body tightly regulates pH and minor fluctuations can cause serious issues or even death. HOWEVER! ;) Malaria was used to treat syphilis. more specifically neuro-syphilis (when the bacteria infects the brain). Julius Wagner-Jauregg won a Nobel prize in 1927 for this, in what was titled Malariotherapy. This technique fell out of favor due to the high death rate associated with it and the development of antibiotics. The theory was briefly resurrected during the height of the AIDS epidemic as it was thought the HIVvirus would bee sensitive to the extremely high fevers associated with malaria parasitic infections...this obviously turned out to not be true.

So it would be reasonable to assume that it may work against other parasites that break down heme, such a trypanosomes (African sleeping sickness) and Leishmania...but I'm not sure if it has been tested widely on those organisms as of yet.

No worries ;) I did a lot of research in malaria so I always love discussing it! Artemisinin actually also works against Schistosoma (blood flukes), which are parasitic flatworms. Unfortunately, the method of action for Artemisinin is still not fully understood, but the most widely held theory is that it somehow interferes with the parasite's ability to break down heme (iron molecule) that it accumulates from digesting blood. This would be consistent with Schistosoma as well.

WRITING.TEXT: It is mainly used to treat P. falciparum, since parasite drug resistant is highest in that strain. However, ACT (artemisinin combination therapy) has been successful in other parasite strains such as P. vivax.

The significance is kind of two-fold. First is sort of obvious from a commercial development standpoint...developing desirable flavors of marijuana for resale (in places where it is legal of course ;). But you could envision another scenario where a range of desirable flavors could be offered to patients who may be using the drug for pain management or appetite stimulation. I'm not a cannabis expert, so I dont know for certain the answer to the second part of your question. However, the based on how the paper is worded it would lead me to believe that the female plants produce much more of the compounds.

WRITING.TEXT: I wouldn't classify it as retrospective. the authors are drawing upon known information about potential metabolic biomarkers and applying novel computational algorithms to determine if they can be used as a potential diagnostic tool. I grant you that 83 subjects is not a very large cohort, but it's a nice size to provide proof of concept. Proper controls were utilize for this analysis..but a large, double blind study will tell the real tale. I'm sure that is where they are looking to tsake this next.

I don't think that the authors would advocate using this analysis as the sole source of diagnosis, in its current state. Given that there haven't been any reliable metabolic biomarkers to date, this a positive first step, but still has a way to go to be used on a regular basis within the clinic.
